Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FESEM images of (a) MnOx at 5 µm scale (b) MnOx at 1 µm scale (c) Mn-Cs(80:20) at 5 µm scale (d) Mn-Cs (80:20) at 1 µm scale (e) Area of EDX pattern and (f) EDX pattern of Mn-Cs (80:20). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM analysis of (a) Mn-Cs(80:20)-Fresh round particle, (b) Mn-Cs(80:20)-Fresh cubicle particles, (c) Lattice fringe pattern in Mn-Cs(80:20), (d) SAED pattern of cubical Mn-Cs(80:20), (e) Mn-Cs(80:20)-Used round particles (f) Mn-Cs(80:20)-Used cubicle particles. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS analysis of (a) O1s in MnOx, (b) O1s in Mn-Cs(80:20) and (c) O 1 s in Mn-Cs(80:20)_used catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Identification and analysis of surface basicity (a) CO2 TPD profile of MnOx and Cs doped variant of Mn (b) CH3OH- IR of MnOx and Mn-Cs(80:20) and (c) Deconvoluted first maxima of CH3OH-IR of Mn-Cs(80:20). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Study of redox properties of catalyst (a) H2-TPR profile for MnOx, Mn-Cs(50:50), Mn-Cs(80:20) and Mn-Cs(20:80) (b) TPO profile of MnOx and Mn-Cs(80:20) and (c) Deconvoluted TPO profile. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 HR-TEM imaging of interface of Mn-Cs(80:20) on the scale of 2 nm having (a) dsp= 0.1923 nm (420) and (b) dsp= 0.2126 (222). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 HR-TEM images of Mn-Cs(80:20) (a) on the interface of nanocubes and nanoparticles (b) Marked area for FFT pattern (c) d spacing calculation from IFFT fringe pattern (d) FFT pattern extracted from HR-TEM images of interface. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Various parameter studies for 5-HMF oxidation to DFF over Mn-Cs(80:20) (a) C-t Profile (b) Pressure effect (c) Effect of temperature and (d) Effect of catalyst loading; Reaction Conditions: 5-HMF= 100 mg, Catalyst= 50 mg, CH3CN= 150 mL, T = 90 °C, PO2= 200 Psig, Rt = 4 h, Agitation speed= 1000 rpm. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Stability analysis of catalyst, (a) Hot filtration test for metal leaching (1) Normal reaction with catalyst (2) Reaction without catalyst after 2 h of reaction and (b) Catalyst recycle run for 5-HMF oxidation to DFF and (c) Effect of solvent, Reaction Conditions: 5-HMF= 100 mg, Catalyst= 50 mg, CH3CN= 150 mL, T = 90 °C, PO2= 200 Psig, Rt = 4 h, Agitation speed= 1000 rpm. Fig. 10 Scheme 1 Various species of methanol adsorbed on the surface of Mn during CH3OH-IR. Chemical Engineering and Process Development, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Pune 411008 India Various compositions of Cs promoted Mn catalysts were synthesized and investigated for selective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF, among which Mn-Cs(80:20) was found to be most efficient giving 91 % conversion of 5-HMF and 99 % selectivity to DFF. Detail characterization like N2-sorption, BET surface area, TG-DTA, XRD, XPS, FE-SEM-EDX, TEM, HR-TEM, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR, O2-TPO, FTIR, Raman spectra and CH3OH-IR were done to establish structure-activity correlation. Enhanced surface area, porosity, thermal stability, dual morphologies were observed due to inclusion of Cs in Mn lattice domain which further enhanced the crystallinity, and oxygen diffusion on the surface. Mixed morphologies comprising nanoparticles (4–5 nm) and nanocubes (50–60 nm) were observed with enhanced redox potential and reduced work function due to weakening of Mn-O bonds. Significant increase in the basicity of catalyst, interfacial redox properties and lattice oxygen led to highly efficient oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF via Mars-van Krevelen mechanism at relatively milder conditions i.e. T = 90 °C and PO2= 200 psig. The catalyst was easily recyclable up to 7 times with minor loss in activity which was regenerated heat treatment protocol. Graphical Abstract Graphical abstract for the selective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF by Mn-Cs(80:20). ga1 Keywords Selective oxidation 5-HMF Polyurethane Heterogeneous catalyst Biomass Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heretofore conventional fossil feedstock used to be the constant source of fine chemicals and fuel globally [1]. Nevertheless, their bulk consumption and decreasing “supply to demand ratio” forced scientific community to look for economically viable and sustainable routes [2]. Production of value added chemicals and fuel additives from biomass are drawing a great attention in recent times. Cellulosic biomass can effectively be converted into various platform chemicals by acid hydrolysis followed by triple dehydration. 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) in particular is one of such attractive platform molecule [3]. U.S. Department of Energy also listed it in “Top 10 + 4″ list of bio-based chemicals [4]. 5-HMF oxidation promises the production of important value added chemicals like 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) and 2,5-furandicarboxyllic acid (FDCA) [5]. Out of these, DFF is a fine chemical of prime importance. It is used as a precursor in various antifungal agents, nematocides, pharmaceutics, porous organic framework, polyurethane and macrocyclic ligands [6]. It also acts as a starting material for various fluorescent materials, poly-Schiff’s bases, organic conductors and as a cross linking agent of poly vinyl alcohol (PVA) for batteries [7]. DFF can be obtained by selective oxidation of less active hydroxymethyl group, rather than highly active α, β-unsaturated aldehyde group of 5-HMF, which is a challenging task (Reaction scheme S1). Earlier, DFF synthesis was attempted by the use of different sacrificial oxidants like 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxide, NaOCl, BaMnO4, pyridinium chlorochromate, pyridine-Pb(OAc)4 trimethylammonium chlorochromate and CrO3-Pyridine [8]. These oxidants pose an environmental threat due to their toxic and hazardous nature. To counter this problem, air or molecular oxygen is considered as a terminal oxidant which is environmentally benign. Reports on several homogeneous catalysts are also documented which include Co/Mn/Zr/Br systems, Mn-salen, Cu based catalysts like CuNO3/VOSO4, CuCl, vanadium phosphate complexes, and Lewis acid (AlMe3) [9]. But these processes suffer from use of harmful oxidants, low efficiency and separation issue. Plenty of reports on heterogeneous catalysts are also known where supported noble metals were used for DFF production. Ru was particularly explored on various supports like activated charcoal, ZrP, ϒ-Al2O3, triazine and mesoporous nitrogen framework [10]. Ru based catalysts were highly efficient for selective oxidation of 5-HMF but longer reaction times and their high price are limitation factors in their use. Kinetic study of chemoselective oxidation of 5-HMF over Pt/ZrO2 was also conducted recently [11]. Among several non-noble metals, vanadium was proved to be highly efficient E.g. V2O5/C showed good efficiency at mild external pressure (40 psig) [12]. Similarly at atmospheric pressure of oxygen, vanadium phosphate intercalated with different metals showed yield of 83–95 % of DFF in toluene and in N, N-DMF [13]. Corma et al. developed V-pyridine complex supported on polymeric mesoporous structure where they achieved 82 % yield of DFF with only 75 % conversion to HMF in 24 h [14]. Although vanadium based catalysts showed promising results yet their toxic nature and tendency to cross polymerize and decarbonylation reduce their efficiency. Many other non-noble metals like Fe, Co, Mn, Ce, Mo and Cu were also assessed for selective oxidation of 5-HMF. Bi(NO3)30.5 H2O and cellulose mediated Cu-NP were developed by Baruah et al. where 82 % yield of DFF was obtained at 80 °C within 2 h in oxygen atmosphere [15]. In another case, use of Cu/MnO2 achieved 96 % yield of DFF in ethanol with 86 % conversion of 5-HMF in 5 h [16]. A magnetically retrievable Mn-Fe combination tested in N, N-DMF with continuous flow of O2 (20 mL/min) for 4 h, gave 82.1 % DFF with almost complete 5-HMF conversion [17]. Mn along with Cu and Al in aqueous solution provided 87 % DFF with 90 % conversion of HMF but with a longer reaction time of 24 h at 90 °C and 120 psig external O2 pressure [18]. A magnetic MOF derived Fe-Co hollow bimetallic catalyst showed 99 % yield of DFF with complete conversion in toluene and alkaline medium at 100 °C and 150 psig pressure of O2 in 6 h [19]. A cryptomelane type MnO octahedral molecular sieves (OMS-2) were also investigated for DFF in N, N-DMF to give 97 % DFF with complete conversion of 5-HMF in 1 h at 110 °C and 75 psig of external O2 pressure [20]. Interestingly, a bimetallic combination of Mo-Ce was examined for single as well as two pot conversion of fructose to DFF. At 120 °C and continuous flow of O2, fructose derived HMF could be completely converted to DFF with 94 % yield [21]. Likewise, sulphated Mo-Zr was tested at higher temperature (140 °C) for fructose derived 5-HMF with continuous flow of O2 till 17 h to achieve 86 % DFF with 99 % conversion of 5-HMF in DMSO [22]. Among several non-noble transition metals, Mn in particular proved to be an efficient catalyst because of its specific surface-lattice oxygen interaction. It is well documented that inclusion of other materials specifically alkali or alkaline metals in Mn structure increases its oxidative tendency because of multifunctional nature and enhanced redox properties in terms of lattice oxygen storage and release capacity [23,24]. This particular aspect forms a strong background to investigate the doped/promoted Mn catalysts which can further improve the sustainability of 5-HMF oxidation to DFF. Here, we report a non-noble alkali promoted metallic nanocomposite, Mn-Cs for 5-HMF oxidation as it provides a dual functionality i.e. oxidation as well as basicity. Various compositions of Mn-Cs were thoroughly screened and best one i.e. Mn-Cs (80:20) was optimized. At 90 °C and 200 psig external air pressure, 91 % conversion of 5-HMF was obtained with 99 % selectivity and 86.8 % yield of DFF. Catalyst was extensively characterized by various techniques to develop structure- activity correlation in a logical coherence. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Mn(NO3)20.4 H2O (97 %), Ca(NO3)20.4 H2O (99.0 %), Cs2CO3 (99.0 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich whereas Fe(NO3)30.9 H2O (98 %), Co(NO3)20.6 H2O (97 %), La(NO3)3.xH2O (99.0 %), K2CO3 (99.5 %), NaOH (96.0 %), methanol (99.8 %), MIBK (99.0 %), toluene (99.0 %) and acetonitrile (99.9 %) were obtained from Thomas Baker Ltd, India. CsNO3 (99.8 %), (NH4)6Mo7O24 (99.0 %), Mg(NO3)20.6 H2O (98.0%) were purchased from Loba-Chemie, India. SrNO3 (99.0 %) was obtained from Merck whereas Ba(NO3)2 was procured from S. D. Fine-Chem Pvt. Ltd. HPLC grade acetic acid with 99.9 % purity was purchased from SRL Chem. Air of high purity (99.99 %) was obtained from Inox-India. 5-HMF (99.98 %) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich whereas DFF (98 %), FFCA (98 %), HMFCA (99 %) were purchased from TCI Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of Mn-Cs nanocomposite Calculated amounts (Table S4) of Mn(NO3)20.4 H2O was taken in an aqueous solution (100 mL) in a round bottom flask and stirred for 0.5 h. To this, 100 mL solution of calculated amount of CsNO3 and 1 M K2CO3 was added which led to precipitation of Mn(NO3)20.4 H2O. The addition of alkalis continued till the pH became 10. After complete addition of CsNO3 solution, the mixture was stirred for 6 h in a nitrogen environment at room temperature. The obtained slurry was filtered and washed by 2 L deionised water till pH of the filtrate became neutral. The wet cake was dried at 110 °C followed by calcination at 450 °C for 5 h with the heating ramp of 10 °C min− 1. 2.2.2 Catalyst screening Catalysts were tested for the reaction in 300 mL Parr autoclave which was equipped with sample and pressure inlet valves. 100 mg of 5-HMF and 50 mg of catalyst were added to 150 mL of solvent and charged into reactor. The reactor was purged 5 times by N2 after which it was heated to the desired temperature with continuous stirring at1000 rpm. After attaining desired temperature, the reactor was charged with 200 psig of oxygen and continued for 4 h. Reaction aliquots were taken after every hour to analyse the reaction progress by HPLC. 2.2.3 Recycling experiments After the reaction, the catalyst was filtered from reaction crude and washed 3 times with ethanol followed by 1 L deionised water. The filtered catalyst was calcined at 450 °C for 5 h. After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst was used again for the recycle experiment. 2.2.4 Analytical methods The reaction samples were filtered with the help of 0.22 μ PTFE syringe filters. The as filtered aliquots were analysed on Agilent 1260 series UHPLC equipped with Multi Wavelength Detector (MWD) and quaternary pump. The analysis was done on Agilent Hi-Plex-H USP L 17 column (100 ×7.7 mm) having 85 % H2O (0.1 % CH3COOH): 15 % CH3CN as mobile phase with 0.6 mL/min flow rate. Other analysis conditions were λ = 280 nm, BW= 4, T = 45 °C and run time 15 min. The conversion, selectivity and yield were calculated by the following equations, Conversion % = Initial mole of 5 − HMF − final mole of 5 − HMF Initial mole of 5 − HMF × 100 Selectivity % = moles of desired product formed moles of 5 − HMF consumed × 100 Yield % = Conversion X selectivity 2.2.5 Characterization methodology Chemisorb 2720 Micromeritics instrument was used to find out the BET surface area of all the catalysts after N2 adsorption at 77 K. XRD was performed in the range of 2θ= 5°− 90° on PAnalytical PXRD system (Model X-Pert PRO-1712). The source was Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) with current intensity, 30 mA; voltage, 40 kV and X-celerator detector. The subtraction procedure of the contribution of the Cu Kα2 line prior to data analysis was conducted using software program X-Pert High Score Plus. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) recordings were performed on ESCA-3000 (VG Scientific, Ltd., England) having a 9-channeltron CLAM4 analyzer equipped with vacuum of better than 1 × 10−8 Torr. Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) was used as the radiation source with constant pass energy of 50 eV. Carbon corrections of all the values of binding energies were performed by taking the C1 s signal (284.6 eV). Particle size, distribution and fringe width pattern were studied by transmission electron microscope (TEM) instrument (model JEOL 1200 EX) whereas HR-TEM studies were conducted on JEOL JEM-F200 HRTEM for material interface calculations. Homogeneous nature of small quantity of solid samples was tested in methanol and 2-propanol with later giving better homogeneity. After formation of homogeneous mixture a drop of it was mounted on the Cu grid which was coated with carbon layers. The sample was heated under infrared lamp before analysis. For analyzing the particle morphology and elemental composition, catalytic samples were subjected to Field Emission- Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM) and Energy Dispersive X-rays Analysis (EDX) respectively (LEO-LEICA SREOSCAN 440 Bruker detector). Micromeritics-2720 (Chemisoft TPx) instrument was used for temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis. CO2 gas was taken as probe molecule to find out the basicity. The analytical protocol was: (i) Samples were heated in the range of 25–200 °C under Helium flow rate of 25 mL/min for degasification, (ii) CO2 was adsorbed at 40 °C and (iii) desorption program of CO2 was run with heating ramp of 10 °C min−1 starting from the adsorption temperature to 700 °C. Perkin Elmer 2000 FTIR spectrometer was employed for the Methanol-IR spectra in the wave number range of 4000–400 cm−1. The reduction profile studies of catalysts were carried out on Micromeritics Autochem- 2920 instrument by H2-TPR. The analysis was done from 50° to 750°C with heating ramp of 5 °C min−1 whereas probe gas used was 10 % H2 in He. O2 TPO studies were conducted using Micromeritics Autochem- 2920 instrument from 25° to 750°C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 using 10 % O2 in He as the probe gas. Horiba JY Lab RAM HR800 micro-Raman spectrometer having 17 mW, 632.8 nm laser excitation was used for calculating the Raman frequencies of samples.Simultaneous thermal analyzer SDT-Q600 Discovery series MS was employed for the calculation of DTA-TGS graph. The solid sample was heated from room temperature to 1000 °C in N2 atmosphere with an increasing rate of 10 °C min− 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Objectives of this work The main objective of this work were (i) Designing a catalyst with enhanced surface properties like basicity, oxygen defects and oxygen mobility for efficient 5-HMF oxidation to DFF (ii) Extensive characterization of catalyst and parameter optimization to establish structure activity correlation (iii) Elucidate the reaction pathway for 5-HMF oxidation to DFF. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Textural studies Comparative XRD plots of different variants of Mn and Cs are shown in Fig. 1a and b. While the undoped MnOx shows moderately crystalline and orthorhombic MnO2 and cubic Mn2O3 phases at 2θ= β = 42.45° (222) and α = 36.99° (013) respectively, Cs doped Mn variants clearly shows multiple valence states along with substantial increase (43 %) in crystallinity ( Table 1, entries 1 and 2). Increased Cs+ content enhanced the appearance of XRD peaks of Mn+4 (2θ= 42.45°, 64.01° and 36.99°) and Mn+3 phases (2θ= 17.66°, 22.10°, 47.99° and 65.20°) along with crystallite size which increase to 16.27 nm for Mn-Cs(80:20) as compared to monometallic MnOx (9.81 nm) [25]. It is also known for enhanced diffusion of oxygen and higher mobility of oxygen in the lattice which was also confirmed by lowering of binding energy in XPS studies [26]. Some peaks related to Mn3O4 phase were also detected at 2θ values of 29.66°, 32.10° and 49.52°. In addition to enhanced valence state and crystallinity, type –IV isotherm with H3 kind of hysteresis loop in N2 sorption studies were observed. It further revealed higher surface area of Mn-Cs(80:20) i.e. 253.79 m2 compared to 190.72 m2 of MnOx and pore size (4.53 compared to 5.03 nm respectively) after doping of Cs (Fig. 1d, Fig. S8 and Table S1). Similar observations were visible in Raman spectroscopic analysis where on inclusion of Cs in lattice prominent decline in the intensity of Lower Energy Level (LEL i.e. 200–400 cm−1) and Higher Energy Level (HEL i.e. 550–75 cm−1) was found which represent the spectral domain of Mn-O skeletal vibrations and Mn-O stretching vibration in MnO6 octahedral lattice respectively (Fig. 1c and Table S3) [27]. This sharp decline in Mn-Cs(80:20) was due to one dimensional growth of nanocubes compared to nanoparticles [28]. 2θ = 36.99° was broken into both higher 2θ as well as lower 2θ revealing presence of uniform compressive strain and uniform tensile strain respectively while phase transformation (Fig. 1b) [29]. FWHM also increased on Cs inclusion in Mn lattice suggesting peak broadening which is in accordance with the thermodynamics indicating about the presence of non-uniform strain too [29]. During phase transformation mass transfer takes place from nanoparticles to nanocubes resulting in shrinking of nanoparticles which generate compressive strain at nanocubes breeding site as shown in Scheme S2. This compressive strain got released after complete formation of nanocubes. A detail account of crystallite size, crystallinity and microstrain in the lattice of catalyst is given in Table 1. 3.2.2 Morphological studies Aforementioned dual morphology was observed in FE-SEM images in Cs doped Mn ( Fig. 2a-d). Spherical nanoparticles as observed in pure MnOx were seen distorted in Mn-Cs(80:20) and formed nanocubes. It is well reported morphological feature attributed to inclusion of alkali metals in Mn lattice [30]. The EDX as shown in Fig. 2e and f revealed 17 % Cs against our theoretical calculation of 20 % Cs. TEM images further affirmed this observation. The average size of round shape particles in fresh Mn-Cs (80:20) were found to be in the range of 4–6 nm whereas for nanocubes, it was 55–60 nm ( Fig. 3a and b, respectively). At higher resolution of 5 nm, fringe pattern was observed with the d110 value of 0.303 nm which is related to MnO2 (Fig. 3c). It was again interesting to note that the cubical morphology was more profound on corners whereas core part was showing majority of round particles. This dual morphology was persistent in the used Mn-Cs(80:20) along with enlarged size which may be due to deposition of carbonaceous reaction crude and reaffirmed by XPS analysis later on. SAED pattern of nanocubes as shown in Fig. 3d possessed symmetrical and fine lattice pattern while that of round shape particle was not uniform as shown in Fig. S4. 3.2.3 XPS The oxidation states of the screened catalysts were studied by XPS. Fig. S2 presents the Mn species in which signature binding energy difference of ∼11.5–11.7 eV for Mn2O3 was observed between the Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 due to spin orbital coupling [31]. Two XPS maxima were observed at B. E. of ∼641.8 eV and ∼653.5 eV corresponding to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. Its deconvolution suggests the presence of Mn (+II), Mn (+III) and Mn (+IV) species on the MnOx surface at the binding energies of 640.7, 641.86 and 643.25 eVs, respectively. A broad satellite peak was also observed at higher B. E. of 645.81 eV due to charge transfer effect in Mn and again confirmed the existence Mn+4 species [32]. These trends were also observed after inclusion of Cs in Mn lattice with slight shift towards lower value of binding energies i.e. 640.53, 641.70, 643.19 and 645.75 eVs. This clearly suggested synergistic electronic interactions of Mn and Cs as it is well known that electron donation takes place from alkali metal to transition metal at their interface which reduces its work function and consequentially binding energy, too [33]. This lowering of binding energy enhances the redox properties of main metals significantly at interface of catalytic surface and reactants [34]. On detailed analysis, it was also observed that the full width at half maxima (FWHM) decreased in case of Mn-Cs(80:20) as shown in Table 2. This may be due to interaction between Mn and Cs and change in electronic properties with change in particle sizes. Fig. 4a and b present the O 1 s deconvolution which represents oxygen species present in MnOx and Cs doped Mn catalysts. Based on binding energy values, oxygen species can be classified into three categories viz. (i) lattice oxygen (O2-) showing peak at the lower Binding Energy (LBE) values ranging from 529 to 530 eVs, (ii) subsurface adsorbed O(OH) and O2 vacancies showing peak at the medium Binding Energy (MBE) values ranging from 530 to 532 eVs and (iii) oxygen of adsorbed water on catalytic surface showing peak in the Higher Binding Energy (HBE) beyond 532 eVs. In monometallic MnOx, three XPS peaks were observed at B.E. values of 529.31, 531.05 and 531.95 eVs suggesting abundance of lattice oxygen followed by O2 vacancy and adsorbed aqueous content. Similar peaks were observed in Mn-Cs(80:20) but with lower intensities. On detailed quantitative analysis it was observed that doping of Cs enhanced the extent of lattice oxygen. Splitting in main peak was observed (Fig. 4b) may be because of different chemical environment of oxygen. Similarly, amount of O2 vacancies also increased at the cost of adsorbed H2O. When compared with reused catalyst, a sharp increase of 17 % was observed in O2 vacancy accompanied by simultaneous with decrease of 12 % in lattice oxygen (Fig. 4c). This reveals the redox nature of Mn-Cs(80:20) catalyst and indicates that reaction proceeded by Mars-Van- Krevelen mechanism due to enhanced lattice oxygen and availability of O2 vacancies [35]. Table 3 presents the binding energy, FWHM and relative percent of oxygen species in both Mn and Mn-Cs(80:20) catalyst. It was observed that binding energy values of Mn species slightly decreased in Mn-Cs(80:20) compared to those in MnOx. This was due to high electro negativity of Mn and easy electron donating property of Cs which led to weak binding energy of Mn-O in doped Mn-Cs(80:20) and enhanced activity of lattice oxygen. 3.2.4 Surface basicity Since alkali and alkaline earth metal are basic in nature, Temperature Programmed Desorption (TPD) using CO2 as a probe molecule was carried out. Fig. 5a represents the CO2 TPD profiles of various Mn-Cs ratios. The observed graph and quantitative estimation revealed that inclusion of Cs in Mn lattice increased basicity of the catalyst significantly ( Table 4, Entries 1–2). In case of bare MnOx, a small peak was observed at 80 °C due to linear interaction of CO2 and surface –OH groups [36]. This peak was retained in almost all the variants except Mn-Cs (70:30). An intense hump was observed at 477 °C with tiny satellite impression at around 533 °C. This can be attributed to desorption of CO2 from oxygen vacancy sites and termed as strong basicity [37]. It was observed that after introduction of Cs in MnOx, these peaks at higher temperature appeared in the form of clear and intense bimodal symmetry suggesting enhanced strong basic properties in catalyst especially in Mn-Cs (80:20). These results were well in accordance with increased oxygen vacancy observed in XPS. Like MnOx, Mn-Cs(80:20) also showed peaks at 80 °C, 451 °C and 546 °C. A tiny spike was also observed at 345 °C which can be because of decomposition of any monodentate/bidentate carbonate species (CO3 2-) formed during adsorption of CO2 on the surface [38]. Similar observations were made for Mn-Cs variants and quantitative estimation is given in Table 4. It was clear that Cs mainly enhanced the strong basicity as bimodal distribution of basic peaks appeared at higher temperature range of 400–650 °C in Cs doped Mn catalysts. It was also observed that with increase in Cs concentration, the strong basicity appeared in the catalyst (Table 4, entries 5–6). This increase in overall basicity can be the region of non-selective oligomerization of 5-HMF since the conversion at this concentration of Cs was highest but no desired products formed while selective and target basic properties produced due to controlled Cs concentration were prolific for the desired product. In order to understand the basic nature of surface –OH group, CH3OH-IR of MnOx and of the most active variant Mn-Cs(80:20) were conducted. The difference of their fresh FTIR and CH3OH-IR is shown in Fig. 5b along with fine deconvolution of maxima of Mn-Cs(80:20) (Fig. 5c). Surface hydroxyl groups having Brönsted basic properties interact with methanol by forming monodentate or bidentate methoxy species as shown in Scheme 1. Both the catalysts, MnOx and Mn-Cs(80:20) showed two bands but with enhanced intensity suggesting increased Brönsted basicity in the later. Asymmetric bimodal maxima were observed at around 1032 cm−1 corresponding to H-bonded molecularly adsorbed methanol [39]. Deconvolution of this maximum is also shown in Fig. 5c suggesting multiple chemical coordinations. Two small peaks were seen at 1106 cm−1 and 1128 cm−1 which could be attributed to monodentate and bidentate methoxy species, respectively, evidencing presence of surface basicity due to O-. Presence of this additional Brönsted basicity could be the reason of high DFF yield from 5-HMF [40]. 3.2.5 Redox properties The reducibility of catalyst was analyzed by H2-TPR as shown in Fig. 6a. Two peaks were observed in all the catalyst samples; one at lower temperature around 270–320 °C and the other at higher temperature in the range of 400–450 °C. It was observed that the lower temperature peaks of catalysts are not symmetric hence these were further deconvoluted as shown in Figs. S10–13. Low temperature peaks correspond to reduction of MnO2 in Mn2O3 whereas higher temperature could be correlated with Mn2O3 reduction to MnO [41]. In the bare MnOx samples, peaks were observed at 287.11 °C, 312.44 °C and 424 °C. When Cs was introduced in MnOx decline in the reduction temperature was observed. For Mn-Cs(80:20) it reduced to 269.33 °C, 300.66 °C and 411.33 °C. This decrease in reduction temperature was due to the fact that on introduction of Cs cation in metal, the strength of Mn-O bond weakened making the lattice oxygen highly mobile and available for desorption [42]. These facts were also supported by XPS investigation where the concentration of lattice oxygen increased and B.E. decreased to certain extent on introducing Cs ion. The desorption of oxygen occur from the interface present between Mn and Cs where Mn has lower valence sites [43]. To know the oxidizability and redox behavior of Mn catalyst due to doping of Cs, TPO was performed and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. The onset of the oxidation of MnOx started at 233 °C whereas for the Cs doped Mn it get started at 227 °C and maximum consumption of O2 was recorded at 538 °C and 526 °C for MnOx and Mn-Cs(80:20), respectively, suggesting strong interaction of Cs and Mn [44]. In the monometallic MnOx, the TPO profile was asymmetric doublet whereas for Cs doped Mn it was triplet suggesting enhanced lattice oxygen in Mn-Cs(80:20) and was in accordance with XPS findings. Oxygen consumption for both the catalysts was almost similar suggesting minimal change in oxygen vacancies which was further supported by XPS. The deconvoluted TPO spectra of MnOx showed peaks at 415 °C, 486 °C and 538 °C whereas for Mn-Cs(80:20), four peaks were observed at 407 °C, 487°, 525° and 573 °C which can be assigned to Mn2O3 and MnO2 species, respectively (Fig. 6c) [45]. 3.3 Activity evaluation Table 5 enlists the detailed catalytic screening for chemoselective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF at reaction temperature of 90 °C and 200 psig of external O2 pressure for 4 h. Various monometallic and alkaline doped catalysts were investigated before finding out the suitability of MnOx and Cs doped Mn as represented in Table S2. Mo and Fe catalysts showed very less conversion and selectivity to DFF was also poor (Table S2, entries 1 and 2). Monometallic Co and Mn catalysts, showed very low conversion of only 25 % and 33 % but the selectivity increased significantly to 81 % and 97 %, respectively, suggesting their strong activity towards oxidative dehydrogenation (Table S2, entries 3 and 4). Mg and Ca doped Mn were not much active as evident by their poor conversion, though Mn-Ba and Mn-Sr showed promising 60 % and 74 % conversion of HMF with 95 % and 99 % selectivity to DFF (Table S2, entries 5–8). Alkali metal doped Mn i.e. Mn-Cs proved highly efficient with 91 % conversion and 98 % selectivity to DFF hence, was used as a catalyst of interest for further studies (Table S2, entry 9). Considering the basic nature of La and Cs, Mn-La and Co-Cs were also tested but poor conversion was observed in this case (Table S2, entry 10–11). Based on these primary catalyst screening results, different combinations of Cs and Mn were screened for selective oxidation of 5-HMF in DFF and the results are shown in Table 5. Among these, Mn-Cs (80:20) proved to be highly efficient (91 % conversion and 99 % selectivity) for 5-HMF oxidation to DFF (Table 5, entry 8). It was observed that amount of Cs higher than 20 % led to higher conversion but selectivity of DFF decreased drastically with condensation product formation. The selectivity of DFF declined to 85 % for Mn-Cs(70:30) from 99 % of aforementioned Mn-Cs(80:20) and it continued to decrease as evident from Table 5, entry 7. Even conversion was decreased for Mn-Cs(50:50), Mn-Cs(60:40), Mn-Cs(70:30) (Table 5, entry 5–7) and though it again increased for Mn-Cs(40:60) onwards (Table 5, entry 4). Higher extent of interface between Cs and Mn is present for small amount of doping which is the active location for oxidative dehydration of 5-HMF [46]. This can be the reason for enhanced activity of Mn-Cs(80:20) even at lower doping, whereas the excess amount of Cs can significantly reduce the interfaces between Cs and Mn leading to decreased activity of catalyst and according to Hedvall effect excessive migration of Cs in the Mn lattice and enhanced distribution in bulk of metal can also decline the catalytic activity [47]. The appearance of these interfaces is clearly visible in HR-TEM images as shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7a shows d420 = 0.1956 nm corresponding to (420) plane of newly generated lattice of nanocubes which is matching with the XRD reflection at 2θ= 47.49° of Mn-Cs(80:20) whereas (222) plane with d222 = 0.2126 nm (Fig. 7b) which was further supported by XRD peak at 2θ= 42.45° of Mn-Cs(80:20) as clearly visible for nanoparticles. The inclusion of Cs in the lattice of Mn initiates the formation of new crystalline surfaces evident by d013 = 0.2574 nm of 013 plane (2θ= 36.99°) as shown by Fig. 8. This process further generated a lattice strain in the Cs doped MnOx which was quite evident by XRD of Cs doped Mn in which the peak at 2θ= 36.99° showed multiplets. The enhanced crystallinity due to doping of Cs seen in XRD was further confirmed by single atomic dot pattern of Mn-Cs(80:20) (Figs. 8.c, S6 and S7). The lowering of work function in Cs doped Mn due to electronic exchange led to enhance redox properties and higher oxygen motility also which was earlier proved by XPS and TPR studies. These elevated redox properties along with surface basic characteristics at appropriately available interfaces of Mn and Cs in Mn-Cs(80:20) were the major reason of higher efficiency of Mn-Cs(80:20). Conversion selectivity profile for Mn-Cs(80:20) was studied for selective oxidation of 5-HMF to get insight of course of the reaction ( Fig. 9a). Since first hour major product was DFF only which suggest the oxidation of hydroxyl group is preferred by Cs doped Mn rather than oxidation of aldehydic group. In the first hour, conversion was only 23 % which increased to 39 % after 2 h with 100 % selectivity to DFF. As the reaction progressed to longer duration, trace amount of FFCA was observed along with 99 % DFF. In third hour of reaction, conversion was 66 % which reached to 91 % at optimized 4th hour of reaction. 3.3.1 Parameter optimization studies Chemoselective oxidation of 5-HMF oxidation to DFF was investigated at various reaction parameters to find out the optimum reaction conditions for the best Mn-Cs(80:20) catalyst (Fig. 9b-d). To get the clear understanding of effect of temperature reaction was studied in the range of 60–120 °C. It clearly shows that at lower temperature conversion of 5-HMF remain very low (27 % at 60 °C) whereas with the increase of temperature brought steep rise in the conversion scale of reaction (Fig. 9c). At 90 °C the best conversion-selectivity profile was observed whereas further increase led to decline in the selectivity of DFF (95 % at 105 °C and 90 % at 120 °C) due to overoxidation of DFF to FFCA. Similar drop in selectivity of DFF was observed at elevated pressure of external O2. Rise in pressure from 50 to 200 psig helped to achieve best selectivity of DFF (99%) but beyond that it decline to 90 % for 300 psig due to further oxidation (Fig. 9b). The reaction was also tested at various concentrations of catalysts by keeping the concentration of 5-HMF constant (100 mg). Evidently at lower concentration of catalyst poor conversion (31 % at 25 mg) was observed due to the obvious reason of unavailability of catalytically active sites (Fig. 9d). At equal concentration of catalysts and substrate (100 mg) 35% FFCA and 4 % FDCA was observed along with 61 % of DFF. Hence 5-HMF/Catalyst = 2 (catalyst=50 mg) was found most suitable and optimum concentration for the chemoselective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF with 91 % conversion and 99 % selectivity. Similar results were obtained for extended run of 5-HMF oxidation as shown in Fig. S14. Complete conversion was achieved after 8 h with significant amount of FFCA (17 %) and trace of FDCA (2 %) on the expense of DFF which led to its selectivity reduced to 78 % only. Other parameter optimization studies like metal loading and substrate loading were also studied as shown in Figs. S15 and S16. 3.3.2 Effect of solvent Influence of reaction media was investigated thoroughly and acetonitrile was found best suitable solvent for selective formation of DFF ( Fig. 10c). Several polar and protic solvents like H2O, CH3OH, polar aprotic solvents like acetonitrile and non polar toluene were screened for 5-HMF oxidation. It was observed that highly polar and protic solvent like water was gave only 47 % conversion with 38 % selectivity to DFF due to 5-HMF oligomerisation. On the other hand, methanol, due to its higher extent of adsorption on the catalytic surface rendered active sites inaccessible to the reactants. This behavior can be explained by higher value of their Synder’s eulotropic coefficient (ε°) which is 0.95 for CH3OH [48]. For acetonitrile excellent solubility of molecular oxygen (8.1) and moderate value of Synder’s eulotropic coefficient (0.65) prevented any kind of competition between reactant and solvent for the catalytic surface [18]. Moderate polarity (dielectric constant = 37) stabilized the active metal cationic center which could be the reason for higher conversion (91 %) and selectivity (99 %) in acetonitrile. In case of MIBK and toluene also the catalyst showed reasonable conversion of 62 % and 58 %, respectively but poor DFF selectivity of 70 % and 67 % which may be due to small value of ε° and less polarity, respectively. 3.3.3 Stability and recyclability of the catalyst Stability of our most efficient catalyst i.e. Mn-Cs(80:20) was investigated by hot filtration and recyclability tests. To exclude any kind of possibilities of metal leaching hot filtration was performed in which the reaction was stopped after 2 h and the catalyst was separated out from the reaction mixture. Then the reaction was resumed without any catalyst for next 2 h. There was no any increase in the conversion was observed as shown in Fig. 10a, ruling out any possibility of metal leaching. This was further proved by ion chromatography studies where no metal traces were observed in the reaction crude (Fig. SI 17). The catalyst recycle efficiency of our catalyst was also evaluated (Fig. 10b). For the first 4 recycle runs the conversion marginally dropped from 91 % to 85 % with DFF selectivity remaining almost constant (95–99 %). From 6th recycle run onwards catalyst started to show rapid decline in catalytic activity with conversion decreasing to 64 % whereas selectivity to DFF also dipped to 90 %. The dramatic decrease in catalytic activity may be due to the deposition of carbonaceous mass as shown earlier by TEM analysis of used catalyst in Fig. 3e and f. 3.3.3.1 Deactivation of the catalyst and factors limiting the process It was observed that after 7th recycle run the conversion profile declined very drastically for Mn-Cs(80:20) catalysts. One of the major reason for the deactivation of Mn-Cs(80:20) on successive reuse can be continuous deposition of reaction crude which cover the active sites of the reaction and make it difficult to access them for the substrate. The deposition of carbonaceous crude was visible both in micrographic analysis (Fig. 3e and f) as well as surface valence studies i.e. XPS of C1s of Mn-Cs(80:20). As shown in Fig. S3 two distinct satellite peaks were observed in C 1 s deconvolution spectra of used Mn-Cs(80:20) catalyst. Peak at 285.99 eV clearly suggested the presence of –C-O moiety whereas distant peaks at 288.07 and 288.77 eV can be attributed to –OH group of alcoholic moiety and >CO groups of reaction media respectively. All these perturbations were well in agreement with reported literature further reaffirming crude deposition on catalytic surface [49]. 4 Plausible reaction mechanism The characterization of the catalyst and the reaction studies suggested that efficient oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF proceeded by the assistance of lattice oxygen of the catalyst via Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. XPS studies revealed 6 % increase in the amount of lattice oxygen after doping of Cs in Mn catalyst. Almost 18 % decline in the lattice oxygen was further observed in used catalyst which indicates its role in 5-HMF oxidation to DFF. Similarly vacant oxygen sites also increased from 32 % of fresh Mn-Cs(80:20) to 49 % of used Mn-Cs(80:20) clearly showing stepwise consumption of lattice oxygen. These oxygen defects are replenished by external O2 though it was observed that the rate of replenishment of oxygen defect is slightly lower which can limit the overall rate of reaction ( scheme 2a). These findings were also supported by the comparison of fresh and used Mn-Cs(80:20) where the amount of Mn+4 was found reduced to 39 % whereas Mn+3 increased to 34 % from 32 % of fresh Mn-Cs(80:20). The higher oxidation state of Mn i.e. Mn+4 which was catalytically active site found to increase to 60 % on Cs doping from 50 % of bare MnOx. Higher oxygen mobility was also reported from the results of H2-TPR and O2-TPO which led to enhanced redox activity of Mn-Cs(80:20). In the first step of Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, the lattice oxygen of Mn-Cs(80:20) was involved in oxidative dehydrogenation of 5-HMF by abstracting the hydroxyl proton (step-I). This would generate reduced centers containing vicinal hydroxyl metal groups in the form of oxygen vacancies due to electronic rearrangement as shown in steps -II and III. This utilization of lattice oxygen species led to generation of O2 vacancies as confirmed by XPS studies. The re-oxidation of catalysts is furnished by O2 gas as per step-IV (scheme 2.b). 5 Conclusion Screening of Cs doped in the lattice of Mn created the best suitable Mn-Cs(80:20) catalyst for the selective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF. XRD studies revealed that inclusion of Cs in Mn lattice domains increased the crystalline nature, mobility of oxygen and oxygen diffusion which were vital for selective oxidation of 5-HMF. Enhanced thermal stability, higher surface area, porosity was established by TG-DTA and N2-sorption profile. Detailed qualitative and quantitative analysis by XPS revealed lowered work function of Mn-Cs(80:20) and binding energy further suggesting mutual synergistic interaction of Mn and Cs. The comparative analysis of nature of O 1 s of MnOx, Mn-Cs(80:20)-Fresh and Mn-Cs(80:20)-spent by XPS established the role of lattice oxygen suggesting that the reaction took place by Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. FE-SEM, TEM, XPS and HR-TEM analysis showed dual morphologies and interfacial redox properties which were further confirmed by H2-TPR and O2-TPO profiles. Cs doping clearly enhanced the basicity of MnOx due to increase in O2 vacancy as found by CO2 –TPD and XPS. CH3OH-IR studies confirmed the strong Brönsted basicity due to different oxide species formed on the surface of Mn-Cs(80:20) which were responsible for 91 % conversion and 99 % selectivity with 86.8 % yield of DFF formed under optimized reaction parameters of T = 90 °C, pO2 = 200 Psig, reaction time = 4 h, agitation speed= 1000 rpm with 5-HMF/catalyst ratio of 2 in 150 mL acetonitrile solvent. coredata.dc:description: Various compositions of Cs promoted Mn catalysts were synthesized and investigated for selective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF, among which Mn-Cs(80:20) was found to be most efficient giving 91 % conversion of 5-HMF and 99 % selectivity to DFF. Detail characterization like N2-sorption, BET surface area, TG-DTA, XRD, XPS, FE-SEM-EDX, TEM, HR-TEM, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR, O2-TPO, FTIR, Raman spectra and CH3OH-IR were done to establish structure-activity correlation. Enhanced surface area, porosity, thermal stability, dual morphologies were observed due to inclusion of Cs in Mn lattice domain which further enhanced the crystallinity, and oxygen diffusion on the surface. Mixed morphologies comprising nanoparticles (4–5 nm) and nanocubes (50–60 nm) were observed with enhanced redox potential and reduced work function due to weakening of Mn-O bonds. Significant increase in the basicity of catalyst, interfacial redox properties and lattice oxygen led to highly efficient oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF via Mars-van Krevelen mechanism at relatively milder conditions i.e. T = 90 °C and PO2= 200 psig. The catalyst was easily recyclable up to 7 times with minor loss in activity which was regenerated heat treatment protocol.
coredata.dc:title: Selective oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF over alkali promoted Mn nanocomposite
